t: Job 20
Zophar’s Sermon on the Wicked Man
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
“Therefore*pn my anxious thoughts make me answer, Because*ld of the turmoil within me.
I*ld have heard the rebuke that reproaches me, And*ld the spirit of my understanding causes me to answer.
“Do*ln you not*i know this of old, Since*ld man was placed on earth,
That*ld the triumphing of the wicked is short, And*ld the joy of the hypocrite is but*i for a moment?
Though*ld his haughtiness mounts up to the heavens, And*ld his head reaches to the clouds,
Yet*ild he will perish forever like his own refuse; Those*ld who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’
He*ld will fly away like a dream, and not be found; Yes,*ld he will be chased away like a vision of the night.
The*ld eye that*i saw him will see*i him*i no more, Nor*ld will his place behold him anymore.
His*ld children will seek the favor of the poor, And*ld his hands will restore his wealth.
His*ld bones are full of his youthful vigor, But*ld it will lie down with him in the dust.
“Though*ln evil is sweet in his mouth, And*ild he hides it under his tongue,
Though*ild he spares it and does not forsake it, But*ld still keeps it in his mouth,
Yet*ild his food in his stomach turns sour; It*ld becomes cobra venom within him.
He*ld swallows down riches And*ld vomits them up again; God*ld casts them out of his belly.
He*ld will suck the poison of cobras; The*ld viper’s tongue will slay him.
He*ld will not see the streams, The*ld rivers flowing with honey and cream.
He*ld will restore that for which he labored, And*ld will not swallow it*i down; From*ld the proceeds of business He*ld will get no enjoyment.
For*ld he has oppressed and*i forsaken the poor, He*ld has violently seized a house which he did not build.
“Because*ln he knows no quietness in his heart, He*ld will not save anything he desires.
Nothing*ld is left for him to eat; Therefore*ld his well-being will not last.
In*ld his self-sufficiency he will be in distress; Every*ld hand of misery will come against him.
When*ild he is about to fill his stomach, God*ild will cast on him the fury of His wrath, And*ld will rain it*i on him while he is eating.
He*ld will flee from the iron weapon; A*ld bronze bow will pierce him through.
It*ld is drawn, and comes out of the body; Yes,*ld the glittering point*i comes*i out of his gall. Terrors*ld come*i upon him;
Total*ld darkness is*i reserved for his treasures. An*ld unfanned fire will consume him; It*ld shall go ill with him who is left in his tent.
The*ld heavens will reveal his iniquity, And*ld the earth will rise up against him.
The*ld increase of his house will depart, And*ild his*i goods*i will flow away in the day of His wrath.
This*ld is*i the portion from God for a wicked man, The*ld heritage appointed to him by God.”
